title_full: SLSOPS01-BP01 Use CloudWatch metrics and automated dashboards to monitor serverless applications
title: Use CloudWatch metrics and automated dashboards to monitor serverless applications
description: Understand Amazon CloudWatch metrics and dimensions for every AWS service you use so that you can put a plan in place to assess its behavior and add custom metrics where appropriate. Use automated cross-service and per-service dashboards to help understand key metrics for the AWS services you use. Use Lambda Powertools or CloudWatch Embedded Metric Format for custom metrics.

title_full: SLSOPS01-BP02 Configure CloudWatch Alarms at individual and aggregate levels
title: Configure CloudWatch Alarms at individual and aggregate levels
description: Configure CloudWatch Alarms at both individual and aggregated levels. Alarm on Duration and IntegrationLatency metrics to quickly identify bad deployments. Aggregate-level alarms should include Lambda metrics (Duration, Errors, Throttles, ConcurrentExecutions), API Gateway metrics, SQS, Kinesis, SNS, Step Functions, EventBridge, S3, and DynamoDB error and latency metrics.

title_full: SLSOPS01-BP03 Define business, customer experience, system, and operational metrics
title: Define business, customer experience, system, and operational metrics
description: Establish metrics across four categories: Business metrics (KPIs measuring application performance against business goals), Customer experience metrics (latency, page load times measured in percentiles), System metrics (HTTP errors, memory utilization, function duration, throttling), and Operational metrics (ticket resolution, on-call pages, CI/CD pipeline stats).

title_full: SLSOPS01-BP04 Implement centralized and structured logging using JSON format
title: Implement centralized and structured logging using JSON format
description: Standardize application logging to emit operational information about transactions, correlation identifiers, and business outcomes using structured logging. Avoid unstructured logging using print or console.log statements. Use JSON as the output format since CloudWatch Logs Insights automatically discovers values in JSON. Use Lambda Powertools logging utilities to simplify and enhance application logging.

title_full: SLSOPS01-BP05 Log correlation IDs and pass them to downstream systems
title: Log correlation IDs and pass them to downstream systems
description: Consistently log correlation IDs and pass them to downstream systems to enable tracing and tracking of individual requests or invocations. As your system grows, use appropriate logging levels and a sampling mechanism to log a small percentage of logs in DEBUG mode. Pass log level configuration to downstream systems for consistent tracing in a microservice architecture.

title_full: SLSOPS01-BP06 Enable AWS X-Ray for distributed tracing
title: Enable AWS X-Ray for distributed tracing
description: Enable active tracing with AWS X-Ray to provide distributed tracing capabilities and visual service maps for faster troubleshooting. X-Ray helps identify performance degradation and quickly understand anomalies, including latency distributions. Service Maps help understand integration points that need attention and resiliency practices.

title_full: SLSOPS01-BP07 Use X-Ray annotations and subsegments for detailed tracing
title: Use X-Ray annotations and subsegments for detailed tracing
description: Use X-Ray subsegments to understand how application logic is constructed and what external dependencies it has. Use annotations (key-value pairs) which are automatically indexed by AWS X-Ray. Combined, subsegments and annotations help quickly identify performance statistics on specific operations and business transactions such as database query duration.

title_full: SLSOPS01-BP08 Use environment variables and external configuration stores
title: Use environment variables and external configuration stores
description: Use environment variables for infrequent changes such as logging level and database connection strings. Use AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store or AWS AppConfig for dynamic configuration such as feature toggles. Store sensitive data using AWS Secrets Manager. Look up values in the function's global scope outside the handler to reduce API calls.

title_full: SLSOPS01-BP09 Implement comprehensive testing strategies for serverless applications
title: Implement comprehensive testing strategies for serverless applications
description: Develop testing strategies through unit, integration, and acceptance tests. Unit tests can run locally without changes. Integration tests should use real services rather than mocks for services you can't control. Create modularized code as separate functions outside of the handler for better unit testability. Take into account service quotas during performance testing.

title_full: SLSOPS01-BP10 Use infrastructure as code and serverless frameworks for deployment
title: Use infrastructure as code and serverless frameworks for deployment
description: Use infrastructure as code and version control to enable tracking of changes and releases. Use serverless frameworks like AWS SAM or Serverless Framework to model, prototype, build, package, and deploy serverless applications. Isolate development and production stages in separate environments to reduce errors from manual processes.

title_full: SLSOPS01-BP11 Implement safe deployments with canary or linear strategies
title: Implement safe deployments with canary or linear strategies
description: When deploying to production, favor safe deployments over all-at-once systems using canary or linear deployment strategies. Use CodeDeploy hooks (BeforeAllowTraffic, AfterAllowTraffic) and alarms for deployment validation, rollback, and customization. Combine synthetic traffic, custom metrics, and alerts to proactively detect errors during rollout deployments.
